subject: Photography
title: The Inverse Square Law
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Inverse Square Law.

hook.text: Double the distance from a light source and brightness drops to one quarter. Physics doesn't negotiate.

buildup.text: The inverse square law governs how light falls off with distance. Intensity decreases as the square of the distance.

discovery.text: This means a subject close to a lamp is brightly lit, but anything a few feet further falls into darkness fast.

twist.text: Photographers exploit this: place subjects close to the light for dramatic falloff, or far away for even illumination.

climax.text: The inverse square law explains why studio lighting placement is measured in inches, not feet.

punchline.text: Move twice as far. Get four times less light.

quiz.question: What happens to light intensity when you double the distance from the source?
options: It drops to one quarter of the original intensity
